Different Crime.Crime Name: Negligence in Search and Rescue Duties

procedure_followed: Plaintiffs filed a lawsuit

decision_made: motion to strike the in personam action is dismissed

legal_basis: Section 43(3) of the Federal Courts Act
application_details: F.C. Yachts is the legal and beneficial owner of both yachts as per the contract. Splash is merely a mortgagee, not a beneficial owner. No change in ownership occurred.
decision_reasoning: Under Section 43(3) of the Federal Courts Act, an action in rem requires the ship to be beneficially owned by the person who was the owner at the time the cause of action arose.
result_of_case: The court dismissed the actions in rem and set aside the warrant of arrest since F.C. Yachts cannot arrest its own ships.
procedure_followed: Motion brought by Splash Holdings Ltd. to set aside the arrest of the first yacht. Heard before Harrington, J., in the Federal Court.
cost_awards: Costs were awarded to Splash Holdings Ltd.

judicial_authority: Federal Court of Canada, Trial Division
procedural_fairness: court reviewed relevant statutes and case law

cause_of_action: entitlement to possession of Tami Joan
possessory maritime lien or right in rem
specific_rule_applied: mortgagee can seize vessel if charterparty impairs security
possessory lien exists while in possession
statutory right in rem ranks below mortgagee's claim
procedure_followed: Federal Court Trial Division reviewed evidence and legal principles
decision_made: plaintiff not entitled to possession, lien, or damages

cause_of_action: Dispute over the disposal of the HMCS Fraser
procedure_followed: Plaintiff initiated an in rem action
obtained a warrant for the ship's arrest
decision_reasoning: Section 14 of the CLPA explicitly bars such actions
result_of_case: The Federal Court quashed the warrant
confirming no jurisdiction to arrest a Crown ship

cause_of_action: Dispute over governance and removal of Chief and Councillors by the Custom Council due to alleged mismanagement.
procedural_fairness: Judicial review applications filed by both parties in Federal Court, with analysis focusing on Custom Council's authority and procedural fairness.
rule_regulation: The Custom Council, as per the Constitution and Election Act, has the power to manage and govern the Band's affairs, including removing the Chief and Councillors for failing to uphold standards of conduct or being absent from meetings without cause.
decision_reasoning: The Custom Council had the authority to remove the Chief and Councillors due to their failure to attend meetings and address concerns.
result_of_case: Resolution 0029052007 was declared valid, confirming the removal of the Chief and Councillors.
application_details: The Chief and Councillors were repeatedly absent from Custom Council meetings and ignored requests to address financial concerns. The Custom Council passed Resolution 0029052007 to remove them, citing mismanagement and lack of accountability.

Different Crime.Crime Name: Making a refugee claim without valid grounds
reasonableness_standard: The standard of review for an enforcement officer's decision on deferral requests is reasonableness.
procedural_fairness: Removal orders must be enforced as soon as reasonably practicable unless specific exceptions apply (e.g., risk of death or inhumane treatment).
evidence_assessment: The H&C application lacked evidence and timeliness; risks paralleled previously rejected claims; family support was deemed adequate.
decision_outcome: Court dismissed the judicial review application, upholding the officer's decision not to defer removal.
review_standard: Federal Court reviewed the CBSA officer's decision under the reasonableness standard, analyzing H&C application validity, risk assessment, and child's best interests.

documentary_evidence: Evidence showed Colombia struggles to protect targeted individuals despite efforts against FARC

legal_basis: Section 36(1)(a) of the Access to Information Act
cause_of_action: Alleged breach of confidentiality during processing of an access request
procedure_followed: Judicial review application filed by Mr. Rowat challenging the Commissioner’s jurisdiction and seeking declarations on constitutional grounds
decision_reasoning: The court dismissed the motion to strike evidence but allowed amendments to challenge section 36(1)(a). The Attorney General was not added as a party, and bifurcation of issues was denied.
result_of_case: Court ruled against striking affidavit evidence, permitted amendment of notice, rejected adding Attorney General, and denied severance of jurisdictional and constitutional issues.
